channel.title: Event formats: using constraints to force better performance
channel.description:
[Tobias Van Scheider](http://us5.campaign-archive1.com/?u=56217f3273816b2f6aa899689&id=48930326c7) - a fun-loving hipster designer at Spotify, talks about tool lust and embracing constraints. He argues that when you don't have all the best, fancy tools, your work becomes better. And when you do have all the best, fancy tools, you need to create constraints.
This gets me thinking of different event formats we could use to get different things done, not just for us, but as open formats we can share with educators around the world.
> The last five years I always participated in the Cannes Young Lions competition, an event by the Cannes Lions Festival. It works like this: On the date of the competition, you get a written briefing from a imaginary client telling you what problem to solve. > > Then you have exactly 24 hours to do it. You are not allowed to ask any questions. 24 hours later you need to upload the deliverable. You are not even allowed to present your work, it has to speak for itself. (In my category "Print Advertising" your deliverable is a one page ad) > > There are many reasons why a competition like this is amazing: > > 1. You only have 24h, get your shit together. > > 2. I don't even work in advertising. It's a completely new challenge for me. > > 3. Limited time means you have to focus on the idea. There is just no time for time consuming execution. That's when you really learn that fancy Photoshop effects or 3D renderings are just distraction unless they ARE the idea. The same goes for writing beautiful code, no one cares. > > 4. Learn to manage your time within just 24h. Don't forget to eat and sleep. Not sleeping might lead to poor decisions in the final hour. But sleeping also means, you lose time. What do you chose? > > 5. You have to balance between what idea to execute. Should you do something that is good for the client, or the big bang that the judges will love to see? These might be two different ideas. > > Constraints breed creativity. They force you to act, to move, think sharp and find a solution. >
Hackathons come to mind, but I challenge you to evolve that (now old) concept. What kind of maker/doer/solver event formats can we think of that build in a specific constraint to push a better kind of outcome?

item.dc:creator: @salim Salim Virani
item.description:
@salim wrote:

This is a nice viewpoint from a content person at a government hackathon: >

I was afraid I wasn’t offering that much. “Now, if anyone had any content needs,” I said, trailing off and looking meaningfully into the distance.

Keeping in mind our intended audience (people involved in the acquisition and procurement processes) and desired tone (professional, reassuring, and a hair more casual than formal), we set to work crafting the copy for a new front page.

One of the most invigorating aspects of content design is to take an idea — half-baked or fully formed — and, with that idea as inspiration, rapidly generate an entire body of copy. Be that text a new front page for a government grocurement tool or the draft of a prose poem, the thrill exists unfettered.

Perhaps my favorite part of this anecdote is that Brad’s and my experience is far from unique: Everywhere you go, you’ll find talented salespeople, marketers, and content designers and strategists eager to lend their skills to the cause of civic good. The primary hurdles hackathon organizers face are recruiting these folks and making them feel at home. Fortunately, these hurdles are easily cleared with the right mindset and approach.

The post then lists out a bunch of tips for attracting non-coders to hackathons, and links to a few guides.

item.title: Event formats: using constraints to force better performance
item.dc:creator: @salim Salim Virani
item.description:
@salim wrote:

This reminds me of a format I tried with @jansn back in the day.

Basically, it was a startup weekend but with mentors only. So the mentors would have their individual startup projects, and have peer-support of other mentor-calibre people with different skills.

Each had their own braintrust and the rule was you had to braintrust and pivot every 4 hours. (You’d call a personal 8-minute braintrust session on-demand.) Everyone was there as support for the others and could be pulled in. The pivoting needed some policing (refering to the time-keeper person) and each pivot was logged on a simple sticky-note dashboard.

It’s how I launched Signally.

Whole team needs to shut down all communication software and hardware for few hours and be focused on thing that we are working on. on every N hours you have 30 mins of your addictiveness called soc. media, communication etc.

so its more set of rules. Maybe blacklist all websites that are not helping etc. Think that it needs half day of prep, then 30 mins of doing that to all participants and then heaven also how I would structure it.

So some people that particiate have one more role and really needs to push for it.

Time/effectivness person - keep track of time an how efective things are going, are we going in circles or we are getting somewhere.

Wrap up person - for each part of discussion (either functionalities, process, idea, any logical chunk) that person is writing down all of important things on sticki notes, and at end of that part sprint does the wrap up with actions, ddl that we need to take. This person is also in charge to bug others for actions and ddls

Do you need help or anything person - one person that acts like PM, except his part of work, he needs to check if others are stuck in something and how they can help, do they need anybody.

item.dc:creator: @salim Salim Virani
item.description:
@salim wrote:

Tobias Van Scheider - a fun-loving hipster designer at Spotify, talks about tool lust and embracing constraints. He argues that when you don’t have all the best, fancy tools, your work becomes better. And when you do have all the best, fancy tools, you need to create constraints.

This gets me thinking of different event formats we could use to get different things done, not just for us, but as open formats we can share with educators around the world.

The last five years I always participated in the Cannes Young Lions competition, an event by the Cannes Lions Festival. It works like this: On the date of the competition, you get a written briefing from a imaginary client telling you what problem to solve.

Then you have exactly 24 hours to do it. You are not allowed to ask any questions. 24 hours later you need to upload the deliverable. You are not even allowed to present your work, it has to speak for itself. (In my category “Print Advertising” your deliverable is a one page ad)

There are many reasons why a competition like this is amazing:

  1. You only have 24h, get your shit together.

  2. I don’t even work in advertising. It’s a completely new challenge for me.

  3. Limited time means you have to focus on the idea. There is just no time for time consuming execution. That’s when you really learn that fancy Photoshop effects or 3D renderings are just distraction unless they ARE the idea. The same goes for writing beautiful code, no one cares.

  4. Learn to manage your time within just 24h. Don’t forget to eat and sleep. Not sleeping might lead to poor decisions in the final hour. But sleeping also means, you lose time. What do you chose?

  5. You have to balance between what idea to execute. Should you do something that is good for the client, or the big bang that the judges will love to see? These might be two different ideas.

Constraints breed creativity. They force you to act, to move, think sharp and find a solution.

Hackathons come to mind, but I challenge you to evolve that (now old) concept. What kind of maker/doer/solver event formats can we think of that build in a specific constraint to push a better kind of outcome?
